title: Andrew Yang brings data dividend onto the US Democratic stage
text:
Right now, our data is worth more than oil. How many of you can remember getting your data check in the mail? It got lost, it went to Facebook, Amazon, Google.

The people who say the crowded debates for selecting the US Democratic presidential candidate are a bore couldn’t be more wrong. In crisp soundbites this Tuesday, 12 hopefuls dug sharp into issues across the impeachment of Donald Trump, the abrupt US withdrawal from Syria, a mandatory buyback of all assault rifles, a wealth tax, Medicare for All, and exactly how old is too old to run for president.

They even discussed how automation is challenging the job economy and possible future policy solutions, such as Universal Basic Income (UBI). On this, which he paints as a $1000 freedom dividend every month for every American, 44-year-old former tech executive Andrew Yang has really carved a niche for himself. He has a terribly long shot at the nomination, but the conversation he is helping mainstream is important and he has got himself a solid enough fandom that goes by the name Yang Gang.

On his campaign website you can buy a t-shirt saying, ‘Math. Money. Marijuana.’

But more importantly, as quoted above, in the Tuesday debate he made the point that data is the new oil, our data should be our property, the scales should be balanced against the Big tech companies, we should share in the gains.
